Hard to answer without units on y, information about which error is being measured, and time and units on x.

It’s difficult to answer your specific question because of the limited detail of the snapshot, but I can do my best to tell you how to tell yourself, and in the future.

For swerve, you can actually get really good PID values by using WPILib’s SysID tool. You can find documentation here, but I don’t think it is particularly excellent for swerve, so I’ll explain how my team handles swerve PID.

From the screenshot you provided, it looks like you’re using PhoenixTuner X to capture data, which tells me that you are using CTRE motors. If you’re using the CTRE generated swerve project (which you definitely should be imo), SysID is really simple. Take a look at CTRE’s documenation on SysID, which is quite good. For swerve characterization, there’s a SwerveRequest specifically for PID tuning. Then, you can use Phoenix Tuner’s Log Extractor to pull the logs, then convert them to wpilogs in the same tool. Finally, load up all of the test data in WPILib’s SysID Tool, and pull data for each motor. Make sure to select the appropriate units. From there, you use those values that you got (just take an average over each motor) and plug them in into the generated TunerConstants file produced by CTRE’s Swerve Builder.

This approach is faster and automates the process of tuning PID gains.
